etymologies: late 18th century (in the general sense): from late Latin recurs- ‘returned’ (from the verb recurrere ‘run back’) + -ive. Specific uses have arisen in the 20th century

definitions: relating to or involving the repeated application of a rule, definition, or procedure to successive results

examples.text: this restriction ensures that the grammar is recursive

shortDefinitions: relating to or involving repeated application of rule, definition, or procedure to successive results

definitions: relating to or involving a program or routine of which a part requires the application of the whole, so that its explicit interpretation requires in general many successive executions
shortDefinitions: relating to or involving program or routine of which part requires application of whole
